science.headline: The Download: chatbots for health, and US fights over AI regulation
science.teaser: This is today’s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. “Dr. Google” had its issues. Can ChatGPT Health do better? For the past two decades, there’s been a clear first step for anyone who starts experiencing new medica
science.tldr: Upholds standards for AI regulation in the US healthcare industry

science.headline: Everyone wants AI sovereignty. No one can truly have it.
science.teaser: Governments plan to pour $1.3 trillion into AI infrastructure by 2030 to invest in “sovereign AI,” with the premise being that countries should be in control of their own AI capabilities. The funds include financing for domestic data centers, locally trained models, independent supply chains, and na
science.tldr: Raises questions about ownership and control of AI technology globally

science.headline: What your breath says about the bacteria in your gut
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00219-2 Metabolites in mouse and human breath correlate to gut-microbe populations and might be helpful in diagnosing disease.
science.tldr: Reveals new clues about gut health through breath analysis

science.headline: Dispatch from Davos: hot air, big egos and cold flexes

science.tldr: Explosively reveals the pompous posturing and petty one-upmanship among Davos attendees

science.headline: Why 2026 is a hot year for lithium
science.teaser: In 2026, I’m going to be closely watching the price of lithium. If you’re not in the habit of obsessively tracking commodity markets, I certainly don’t blame you. (Though the news lately definitely makes the case that minerals can have major implications for global politics and the economy.) But lit
science.tldr: Increases may impact industries reliant on lithium for battery production

science.headline: Marvellous microbes, memory and the multiverse: Books in brief
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00241-4 Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.

science.headline: Sea turtles may be more resilient to global warming than we thought
science.teaser: An “epigenetic” adaptation could prevent large numbers of loggerhead turtles from hatching as female due to climate change – a threat that was feared to lead to population collapse
science.tldr: Prevents potential extinction from sea turtles adapting to climate change

science.headline: Bone cancer therapy unexpectedly makes tumours less painful
science.teaser: A drug that kills cancer cells by puncturing them comes with an additional benefit: tests in mice suggest it reduces the growth of pain-sensing nerves around tumours
science.tldr: Alters treatment options for bone cancer patients with reduced pain

science.headline: Peter F. Hamilton's latest is an epic slice of sci-fi – with one flaw
science.teaser: Peter F. Hamilton’s new book A Hole in the Sky is set on a troubled ark ship hundreds of years into its voyage, with fantastic plot twists and turns. I'm a big Hamilton fan, but one aspect of the novel proved alienating for me, says Emily H. Wilson
science.tldr: Unveils an epic sci-fi tale with fantastic plot twists and turns

science.headline: Why singing, dancing and engaging with art is good for your health
science.teaser: Whether it be singing, dancing or crafting, engaging in the arts is good for our health, and we're beginning to understand how this behaviour affects our biology
science.tldr: Boosts overall well-being by reducing stress and increasing happiness

society.headline: The Rise of the Tech Hamiltonians
society.teaser: The political coalition that has formed under Trump’s banner has the potential to reshape American politics.
society.tldr: Challenges American politics as it has been known for decades

society.headline: James Goldsmith, godfather of British populism
society.teaser: Unlike Nigel Farage or Rupert Lowe, Goldsmith told the truth
society.tldr: Challenges prevailing narratives about British populism with truthful assertions

society.headline: The Country That Made Its Own Canon
society.teaser: When Sweden named its national treasures, the list was condemned as blinkered and dated. But it was also a chance to see the country anew.
society.tldr: Reevaluates Sweden's cultural heritage and challenges outdated national identity

society.headline: Police and ICE Agents Are on a Collision Course
society.teaser: After another fatal ICE shooting in Minneapolis, the rift between local police and federal agents is becoming a rupture
society.tldr: Escalates tensions between local police and federal agents nationwide

society.headline: The Cruelty and Theatre of the Trump Press Conference
society.teaser: During the President’s second term, he and his staff have made the media briefing his signature rhetorical form.
society.tldr: Demonstrates how the Trump press conference has become a key rhetorical form

society.headline: William Eggleston’s Lonely South
society.teaser: In his show “The Last Dyes,” the photographer presents a world that feels fictional but fact-based.
society.tldr: Reveals a hauntingly familiar American South through Eggleston's lens

society.headline: The Rumbles Within Trump’s GOP
society.teaser: The president’s fixation on Greenland has posed yet another test for Republican leaders.

society.teaser: The factions that could take him to power are already forming

society.headline: No one can govern Scotland
society.teaser: Neither a grand coalition nor a majority government are likely at the May elections
society.tldr: Negotiates will require significant concessions from any party in power

society.headline: The Four Types of Trump Supporter
society.teaser: The president’s political power depends on his ability to play different roles for different parts of his coalition.

society.headline: The Online World Where Iranians Were Free
society.teaser: Iran’s internet blackout is yet another act of state violence.
society.tldr: Reveals the extent of state control over citizens' online freedom

society.headline: Tarring and Feathering, American Style
society.teaser: What began as a European folk practice became a distinctly American ritual of public punishment. The post Tarring and Feathering, American Style appeared first on JSTOR Daily .
society.tldr: Demonstrates how a European practice was uniquely adapted in America

society.tldr: Slips up by exposing vulnerabilities in ICE's presence northward
